content.raw:
The logging server is well tested (with a test suite), and while the client code doesn't have a test suite, I've run some labscript programs with it and things seem to work fine.

I'll merge next Monday if there are no objections.
content.html:
The logging server is well tested (with a test suite), and while the client code doesn't have a test suite, I've run some labscript programs with it and things seem to work fine.

I'll merge next Monday if there are no objections.

content.raw:
I tested the logging server with our system and it seems to work fine except for one thing I am wondering about:

When opening for example blacs or labscript, one \(for runmanager\) or several \(for blacs\) files are created named “test\_can\_create\_file-xyz“ where xyz is a long list of numbers and letters looking like some tag. Which part does create this file? It also seems to have no content.
content.html:
I tested the logging server with our system and it seems to work fine except for one thing I am wondering about:

When opening for example blacs or labscript, one (for runmanager) or several (for blacs) files are created named “test_can_create_file-xyz“ where xyz is a long list of numbers and letters looking like some tag. Which part does create this file? It also seems to have no content.

content.raw:
Thanks for testing!

That file is the server testing ahead of time that it can create files in the directory, so that it can warn the client that log rotation won't work if it can't (this is not foolproof, since permissions may change between then and log rotation, but it will catch most issues).

There was a bug where the server didn't delete the test file after confirming it could create it. This [should be fixed now in zprocess 2.8.4](https://bitbucket.org/cbillington/zprocess/commits/1fce35d1181b3dfc2b10aa1081b05f06733a2b4b).
content.html:
Thanks for testing!

That file is the server testing ahead of time that it can create files in the directory, so that it can warn the client that log rotation won't work if it can't (this is not foolproof, since permissions may change between then and log rotation, but it will catch most issues).

There was a bug where the server didn't delete the test file after confirming it could create it. This should be fixed now in zprocess 2.8.4.
